profileText: A Senator from Michigan; born in Chatham, Province of Ontario, Canada, August 26, 1872; attended the public schools of Chatham; moved to Detroit, Mich., in 1890; railroad car checker 1890-1897; clerk in the coal business 1897-1903; was associated with the Ford Motor Co. in the manufacture of automobiles 1903-1919; president of the Bank of Detroit and director of the Detroit Trust Co.; commissioner of street railways 1913-1915; commissioner of the metropolitan police department 1916-1918; mayor of Detroit 1919-1922; appointed November 29, 1922, as a Republican to the United States Senate and elected on November 4, 1924, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Truman H. Newberry; on the same day was elected for the term commencing March 4, 1925; reelected in 1930 and served from November 29, 1922, until his death on October 22, 1936; unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1936; chairman, Committee on Civil Service (Sixty-ninth Congress), Committee on Education and Labor (Sixty-ninth and Seventieth Congresses), Committee on Interstate Commerce (Seventy-first and Seventy-second Congresses); philanthropist; died in Detroit, Mich.; interment in Woodlawn Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1903-1940. 32,000 items. General letters, speeches, articles, subject files, addresses, clippings, and scrapbooks. Including material relating to Couzens' service with Ford Motor Company, mayoral campaign, and Senate tenure. Finding aid.
Correspondence in David E. Finley papers, 1921-1977, regarding controversy between Andrew W. Mellon, secretary of the treasury and Couzens over a tax reduction plan.
Correspondence in Arthur Atwood Ballantine papers, 1901-1964. Finding aid.
1924-1935. Ca. 100 items. Correspondence with Chase S. Osborn, former governor, concerning Couzens' stand on prohibition; and correspondence with William M. Hauser regarding banking legislation.
